analyzeResult.content:
SEP-18-95 MON 17:04 RK&H
SEP-18-1995 11:10
FROM KRASSA KLMLI & MADSEN LLC TO
Juliet Wittman
Where there's smoke, . there's ire
Bonider's Great Smoking can't really take sides on Controversy, I was an tore pentant and - I now realize - highly inconsiderate smok- or for years. I remember getting hutty when asked not to smoke; birthely blowing smoke across a friend's dinner plate while she was still caung having trouble refrain- Ing from lighting up while visiting the hospital
In all fairness, the social climate then was different. We all knew that cigarettes caused cancer, but wę somehow managed to forget that while actually sucking in those fragrant curls of smoke. Smoking was acceptable, It was glamorous. It was associated with being sophisticated, Intense, slightly wicked. Writers smoked. Movie stars smoked. Handsome, laconic cowboys . trailed clouds of smoke as they cantered Into the sunset.
When bored, you Hit Up. Nervous, you lit up. There were a thou- sand firtatious things you could do with a cig- zrette. It provided the perfect ending to a' rich meal; a quiet moment of commu- Dion after sex; a spur to get you going in the morning
FAX NO. 303 740 9590
P. 06/06
7409590 P.05
Boulder Daily Camera FIT Section September 18, 1995
2070059001
TOTAL P.05
How could anyone but a narrow, artless, humorless killjoy object?
It took practice for me to get fully addicted. I started trying when I first came to America at the age of 17. I wanted to be accepted, and all the popular girls smoked. Trouble was, I hated It. It took me a year of sneaking my mother's Salemi to' develop a taste for nicotine. But I developed it with a vengeance. All the events of my 20s took place ir a baze of smoke. I was so addicted that I once forfeited my grade in a college course because I couldn't sit through a 3-hour exam without a cigarette.
Quitting, which I tried several times, was unbelievably dlideult I finally succeeded when I decided I would never light up agata, only staal put's from my husband's cis-
All the events of my 20s took place in a baze ot smoke.
logic behind that ?. I became his shadow, hungrily Inhaling whenev. er he lit up. The breakthrough came when we were separated for an entire afternoon. Jhtering into the evening. I decided that if 1 could abstain .for four hours, I could abstain for the rest of my life.
It took a while for the craving to subside. I loved sitting near a smoker, trying to anulf up his sec- ondhand smoka. Later, I discov- ered that secondhand smoke gave me a sore throat and & general feeling of malaise plus - madden- ingly - a renewed craving for nico- tine.
I gained weight. I bad dreams in which I found myself with a ciga. rette in my hand and couldn't remember when I'd Ult it up, or why. I stayed'off cigarettes primarily because I sin- ply couldn't, boor the idea of having to quit again:
It's been 20 years since I last smoked, and I no longer harbor the slightest desire for ciga rettes. My husband quit, too: my datighter never started. Now, when I seo a teenager strolling the mall with that ubiqui- tous white cylinder between her lips, I have to suppress the urge to match it away.
I don't have any spe- diffe tips for quitting other than to col well, exercise and try to be happy II think cigarettes are often tarod to alleviate mild depression). And persevere. It's worth It. Really.
As for the local debate, I think non-smokers should be able to go to bars erai restaurants without having someone else's smoke slide down their throals. And I also think smokers have a right to congre. gate and enjoy themselves in pub- Lic. I don't know which is more annoying, the self-righteousness of the militant anti-smoking brigade, or the smokers' rante about total- itarian government. Surely & cotn- promise can be found
Stuff toriter Juliet Wittman in the author" of . "Breast Cancer
.
